thread.title_full: Just what we need - 7 Tory MPs form band to enter Eurovision Song...

author: TristanCork
title: Just what we need - 7 Tory MPs form band to enter Eurovision Song...
text:
Just what we need - 7 Tory MPs form band to enter Eurovision Song Contest By TristanCork | Posted: October 11, 2015 Eurovision Song Contest Just what we need - 7 Tory MPs form band to enter Eurovision Song Contest X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
It appears World War Three might be about to break out, austerity is beginning to bite in Britain and everything from housing and health to transport and pensions have the word 'crisis' put after them every day. 
But seven Tory MPs – many of them newly-elected to parliament – have done just what the nation needed right now, and formed a rock band to enter the Eurovision Song Contest with a ditty about how they want Britain to leave the European Union. 
The seven will be fronted by a female singer, Andrea Jenkyns, who was a surprise victor over former Shadow Chancellor Ed Balls in May, with six backing musicians made up of backbench Conservative MPs. 
Two of those are from the West – Somerton and Frome's David Warburton on piano and Culture Select Committee chairman and Hereford MP Jesse Norman on trumpet. 
The band is expected to be called House of Cerulean, after the shade of deep blue, and the band are hiring out a 'rehearsal room' in the Houses of Parliament, to get together. The band has eyes on playing armed forces' galas and the like next summer, and are up for entering the Eurovision Song Contest as Britain's representatives next year. 
"We have booked a rehearsal room in the Commons later this month for our first try-out together: at the moment, we can't even be sure that we will gel together musically," said Ms Jenkins. "If we do, who knows. There is an armed forces gala next June which would be a good moment to perform. 
"We agreed it would be hilarious to enter a sceptical song into the Eurovision Song Contest, such as Queen's 'I Want To Break Free'," she added, appearing to momentarily forget that pretty much the only rule about the Eurovision Song Contest is that the song has to be an original. 
She stressed that it was still early days for the band and no final decision had been made on the name or set-list.
